[[File:Donato Giancola - J.R.R.Tolkien Portrait.jpg|thumb|400px|''J.R.R.Tolkien'' by [[Donato Giancola]]]]'''Canon''' is a term to refer to consistent "absolute truth" in literature
column3: in contrast to apocryphal tales of "lesser" significance and value. Many sophisticated works of fiction have some canon that refers to the corpus of the officially-released works and aims to internal consistency. For a full definition

column1: It is difficult to speak of what is "true" in the context of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s [[legendarium]]
column2: or which texts should be considered part of the  '''canon'''.

column1: ==Publication History==
{{quote|...there are Tolkien's latest thoughts
column3: and his published thoughts and these are not necessarily the same.|''[[Tolkien's Legendarium|Tolkien's Legendarium: Essays on The History of Middle-earth]]''}}

column1: There are various reasons that make the idea of a Tolkien canon problematic:
* Tolkien worked on Middle-earth over the course of decades
column2: making substantial changes.  Readers may remember
column4: the differences between ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings'' with regard to [[Gandalf]] and the [[Elves]].  Moreover
column5: toward the end of his life the focus of his writing shifted from pure storytelling to more philosophical concerns
column6: which led to a considerable shift in tone and content.

column1: * Tolkien's writing is laden with details and hints
column3: especially in the posthumously published work. Such information should not take precedence over more explicit statements elsewhere
column4: but it can help to flesh out our understanding of Middle-earth (even if it does at times add confusion).  In general
column5: the '''revised''' versions of ''The Hobbit'' and the ''Lord of the Rings'' are considered canon
column6: but with ''The Silmarillion'' and other posthumous texts the matter is more complex.

column1: * To add to the confusion
column3: Tolkien intentionally left some gaps in his works. In [[Letter 144]] he provided both an explanation and an example of this
column4: writing that ''"even in a mythical Age there must be some enigmas
column5: as there always are.  [[Tom Bombadil]] is one (intentionally)."''  Giving an incomplete picture in this way can be frustrating
column6: but it also makes the invented world feel more natural.

column1: {{quote|I am doubtful myself about the undertaking. Part of the attraction of the [[The Lord of the Rings|L.R.]] is
column3: due to the glimpses of a large history in the background: an attraction like that of viewing far off an unvisited island
column4: or seeing the towers of a distant city gleaming in a sunlit mist. To go there is to destroy the magic
column5: unless new unattainable vistas are again revealed. Also many of the older legends are purely 'mythological'
column6: and nearly all are grim and tragic: a long account of the disasters that destroyed the beauty of the Ancient World
column7: from the darkening of [[Valinor]] to the Downfall of [[Númenor]] and the flight of [[Elendil]].|''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''

column1: As only ''[[The Hobbit]]''
column4: and ''[[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|The Road Goes Ever On]]'' were published during Tolkien's lifetime
column5: only those works should be considered "true" canon with respect to Tolkien's publication history. Tolkien himself considered the published works as "fixed" and tried not to introduce new concepts that would contradict or alter them

column1: But ''The Hobbit'' was revised twice
column2: and ''The Lord of The Rings'' once.  There is no general consistency across all of these books
column3: although the most agreement between sources may be found with the second (1950) edition of The Hobbit
column4: the first (1954-5) edition of ''The Lord of The Rings''
column5: and ''The Adventures of Tom Bombadil'' and ''The Road Goes Ever On''.

column1: [[Christopher Tolkien]] compiled an approximation of what his father might have produced when ''[[The Silmarillion]]'' was published.  However
column2: he warned readers not to look for consistency between this book and those published by his father.  Throughout his commentaries in ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]''
column3: Christopher has pointed out many discrepancies between his final editorial selections and alterations and what he later believed would have been his father's true intentions.

column1: Furthermore
column2: the chapters in the published ''Silmarillion'' about the ruin of [[Doriath]] and the fall of [[Gondolin]]
column4: were largely written by Christopher Tolkien and [[Guy Gavriel Kay]]
column5: to fill in gaps in the available story
column6: and therefore do not represent J.R.R. Tolkien's own ideas about how those stories should be handled.

column1: ''[[Unfinished Tales]]'' consists of essays and stories composed after ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' which were generally consistent with The Lord of the Rings.  The book reveals parallel traditions regarding the history of Galadriel and Celeborn
column3: and a few minor sub-plots.  Although some people{{who}} argue that the book is generally acceptable as canon
column4: readers must bear in mind the fact that no true consistency exists between these unfinished tales and the earlier works.

column1: The various texts published in ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'' date from all periods of Tolkien's life and generally exclude the more finished sections used for the published works.
==Determining a priority==
When handling two or more inconsistent elements of Tolkien's legendarium
column2: there are at least two (sometimes overlapping
column3: sometimes conflicting) rules of thumb according to which a Tolkienist can apply criticism and determine which is more valid over the other.

column1: ;Final intent
:This principle follows the axiom that Tolkien's legendarium is a work that was revisioned towards maturity and refinement
column2: therefore later ideas are more valid than earlier ones. For example
column3: in one of his [[Last Writings]] (q.v.) near the end of his life
column4: Tolkien wrote that the [[Blue Wizards]] played a big role in the [[East]]. This can be considered the "final word" on the matter
column5: obsoleting an earlier idea (stated in [[Letter 211]]) that they fell like Saruman.

column1: ;Height intent
:This principle considers that by the writing of the ''Lord of the Rings'' the legendarium had reached its peak of maturity. Afterwards
column2: Tolkien's personal and unpublished writings presented a "decline" and were mainly experiments with philosophical matters of Arda
column3: which sometimes contradicted the established works. These were eventually abandoned or left unfinished. Such concepts include the [[Round World version of the Silmarillion]]
column4: or the [[1960]] partial rewrite of ''The Hobbit''.

column1: ==Individual Issues==
===Gil-galad===
An example of the canon question is the lineage of [[Gil-galad]].  In the published ''Silmarillion'' he is said to be the son of [[Fingon]]
column2: but as disclosed in ''[[The War of the Jewels]]'' Tolkien considered many arrangements before apparently deciding that he was the son of [[Orodreth]]
column3: who would then also be displaced as a son of [[Finarfin]] and turned into Finarfin's grandson instead. Also
column4: most people think [[Finwë]] had three children
column5: all sons; [[Fëanor]] by his first wife [[Míriel]]
column8: since he also had two daughters
column10: by his second wife (Findis was in fact Finwë's first child by Indis)
column11: thus Finwë had five children. If the published ''Silmarillion'' is taken as canon all later material must be discarded
column12: but if the later writings by Tolkien are taken as canon the ''Silmarillion'' must be rewritten
column13: a task which Christopher Tolkien has stated he will not do as he is now retired. So we are left with a ''[[Quenta Silmarillion]]'' which contradicts the original author's intentions
column14: but which is the only authoritative narrative in existence for most of the traditions.  The latter third of the ''Quenta Silmarillion'' in particular was never rewritten by Tolkien as a whole after the early narrative of his youth.

column1: ===''The Hobbit''===
A further problem is reconciling ''The Hobbit'' with ''The Lord of the Rings''.  In 1947
column4: that ''The Hobbit'' required revision to make it more consistent with the then nearly finished sequel.  In 1950
column5: Tolkien was surprised to be informed that the publisher had incorporated his 1947 suggestions into a new edition of ''The Hobbit''. When he received the proofs for this update he subsequently altered some of the as-yet unpublished material in ''The Lord of the Rings'' to more fully conform to the changes Allen & Unwin had made to ''The Hobbit''.

column1: Among inconsistencies which survived into the second edition
column2: [[Bilbo Baggins|Bilbo]] and the [[Dwarves]] took far too long to reach [[Rivendell]] when a map from ''The Lord of the Rings'' was used to gauge the distance
column3: which can only be explained with great difficulty if at all. There are additional problems as well
column4: such as the exact location of the [[Trolls|Troll]] encounter. When he began writing ''The Hobbit'' Tolkien did not intend for it to be part of his Middle-earth mythology
column5: but was simply populating an imaginary landscape with characters and locations for a children's adventure story.  Nonetheless
column7: Tolkien borrowed several references to his unpublished mythology to give the story a sense of depth. Thus Gandalf and [[Thorin]] wield swords from [[Gondolin]]
